title: ASX to rise, Dow resets record on earnings, economic data
summary: Australian shares are poised to open higher. Dow closes above 34,000 for first time. US 10-year bond yield plunges. China GDP pending.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are poised to open higher, following a broad record setting rally on Wall Street with the Dow breaching and closing above 34,000 for the first time. The yield on the 10-year US note was 6 basis points lower to 1.56 per cent at 4.59pm in New York.', 'ASX futures were up 15 points or 0.2 per cent to 7051 near 7am AEST. The currency edged 0.4 per cent higher.', 'US stocks surged after retail sales there rose by the most in 10 months in March, reinforcing optimism about the economic outlook as the pace of vaccinations accelerates.', 'At the close, the Dow was up 305 points or 0.9 per cent to 34,035.99; it earlier rose as high as 34,068.73. Twenty three of its 30 components were higher, paced by UnitedHealth and Amgen.', 'The S&P 500 was up 1.1 per cent; nine of its 11 industry groups were higher, led by real estate, information technology and health care. The Nasdaq was up 1.3 per cent.', 'Coinbase Global slipped 1.7 per cent; bitcoin was up 1.9 per cent to $US63,400; Tesla edged up 0.9 per cent. Gamestop tumbled 6.1 per cent.', '“Forget about asset class correlations and all that, it’s a dream day for #investors as portfolios benefit simultaneously from higher prices for #Stocks #Bonds Commodities #Bitcoin #Dollar,” Mohamed El-Erian tweeted. “And a dream set of drivers: Fundamentals/data, #Fed remarks, #risk appetites and flows”', '“There seems to have been very little participation from active equity managers in the last 1.5 per cent move higher in the S&P 500 with essentially zero excess flow over the past week,” Axi’s Stephen Innes said. “It is no surprise that ‘active equity manager’ positioning also remained unchanged week-on-week and has now been slightly underweight for more than a month.', '“At the same time, cash and options volumes have made new year-to-date lows. So why is the market up?” Mr Innes asked: “In a quiet tape like this, it seems that passive/systematic flows – which are to buy – have been enough to push the market higher.”', 'US retail sales rebounded 9.8 per cent last month, the largest increase since May 2020, the Commerce Department said. March’s rise pushed the level of sales 17.1 per cent above its pre-pandemic level and to a record high.', 'Economists polled by Reuters had forecast retail sales would increase 5.9 per cent in March. Retail sales surged a record 27.7 per cent on a year-on-year basis. Data for February was revised higher to show sales dropping 2.7 per cent instead of 3.0 per cent as previously reported.', 'The latest update from the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention reported that 125.8 million Americans have received at least one vaccine shot, representing 37.9 per cent of the total population.', 'The CDC said 48.3 per cent of those aged 18 years and older have received at least one dose; that rises to 80 per cent for those aged 65 years and older.', 'The US listed shares of both BHP and Rio closed higher, bolstered by metals markets. Iron ore, copper and aluminium rose. Gold gained too.', 'The spot price for iron ore leapt 2.8 per cent to $US178.41 a tonne, according to Fastmarkets MB.', 'The firm said its index for iron ore 65 per cent Fe Brazil-origin fines, cfr Qingdao rose to a record high, with “the surge supported on demand for high-grade iron ore due to mills’ healthy margins”. Fastmarkets listed the price at $US211.10 a tonne, up $US6.10 on the day.', 'Benchmark three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange (LME) was up 2.2 per cent at $US9278 a tonne by 1610 GMT, after touching a six-week high of $US9299.', 'Goldman Sachs said copper could reach $US15,000 a tonne by 2025. It also raised its 12-month target to $US11,000 per tonne and projected an average of $US9675 in 2021.', '“(Higher prices) should stimulate a wave of so-far absent mine supply investment, but if that does not start to materialise or demand surprises to the upside then an even higher price path is probable,” the bank said.', 'Citi said on Monday copper consumption could “materially overshoot our base forecasts in 2021”, as it recommended clients take bullish copper exposure over the next few weeks.', 'Aluminium was up 0.6 per cent to $US2337.50 per tonne after hitting its highest level since May 2018 at $US2356.50.', 'China will report March industrial production and retail sales as well as first-quarter GDP on Friday. Here’s what TD Securities is expecting: “A very low based in March last year will make this month’s China data look overly impressive. Nonetheless, the underlying picture presented by this month’s data dump will likely be a positive one.”', '“Industrial production is likely to record a solid 18 per cent y/y gain (consensus: 19 per cent), with output continuing to be helped by strong exports demand and strengthening domestic momentum.', '“We see upside risks to retail sales and look for a 30 per cent y/y increase (consensus: 28.5 per cent).', '’“Last but not least, GDP is likely to record a small gain on the quarter (consensus: 1 per cent q/q), but on y/y basis is likely to look particularly strong (consensus: 18.2 per cent) given the weakness in Q1 last year.”'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: New Zealand BusinessNZ manufacturing PMI March', 'Overseas data: China first quarter GDP, March industrial production and retail sales; The country’s debt is also forecast to rise to 159.8 per cent of gross domestic product at the end of 2021.', 'Prime Minister Mario Draghi’s cabinet approved its economic update Thursday, forecasting economic growth at 4.1 per cent in 2021 and targeting it at 4.5 per cent once stimulus measures and other legislation are factored in, the official said.', 'France on Thursday became the latest country to record more than 100,000 deaths due to COVID-19.', 'The threshold was reached after 300 fatalities were registered over the past 24 hours, bringing the official toll to 100,077, a spokeswoman for the French public health authority said by phone.'], 'Asia': ['China and Hong Kong stocks fell on Thursday, as worries about policy tightening mounted ahead of China’s first-quarter GDP data due on Friday.', 'The CSI300 index fell 1.6 per cent to 4902.74 by the end of the morning session, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.2 per cent to 3376.30.', 'The Hang Seng index dropped 1 per cent to 28,623.90, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index lost 1.5 per cent to 10,831.14.', 'Analysts and traders said China’s tightening had begun and more upbeat economic data would reinforce Beijing’s tightening bias.', 'China will publish on Friday its first-quarter GDP data, along with March data on retail sales, industrial output and urban investment.'], 'Currencies': ['TD Securities take on FX markets overnight: ”After catching a strong bid before the equity open, the typical high beta dollar bloc currencies have steadied despite UST yields coming off rather sharply and equity markets catching a bid post-US retail sales.', '“At the same time, EURUSD rejected the notable 1.1990/00 resistance area. We’ll be keen to see whether the market holds onto these gains and can respect resistance (in the case of EURUSD) into the weekend. We’re particularly mindful of USDCAD as the Bank of Canada may be setting up for a hawkish surprise.”', 'Coinbase IPO sparks rush for ‘picks and shovels’ crypto assets: Investors of all sizes are hoping to emulate the success of Westpac’s venture arm, which stands to make a $500 million gain from its Coinbase investment.', 'The big question mark over the RBA’s bond buying program: Economists still expect the Reserve Bank will extend its quantitative easing program but the point at which its buying distorts the market for government bonds is up for debate.'], 'Commodities': ['Whitehaven stumble brings Tinkler tensions to the boil: Past and present shareholders in Whitehaven Coal are fuming over a 24 day period punctuated by insider selling and two downgrades to coal sale forecasts.', 'The World Steel Association is forecasting that steel demand will grow by 5.8 per cent in 2021 to reach 1,874.0 million tonnes (Mt), after declining by 0.2 per cent in 2020. In 2022 steel demand will see further growth of 2.7 per cent to reach 1,924.6 Mt.', '“The current forecast assumes that the ongoing second or third waves of infections will stabilise in the second quarter and that steady progress on vaccinations will be made, allowing a gradual return to normality in major steel-using countries,” the steel group said.'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['Rallying shares ignite valuation warnings: The ascent of the Australian sharemarket back to near record levels is ringing alarms for fund managers, with Investors Mutual joining a growing chorus pointing to sky-high valuations as a risk for markets.', 'ASX rises 0.5pc, edging closer to record as miners rally: The ASX advanced to a post-pandemic high on Thursday as miners helped to push the market closer to last year’s record.', 'Capping super contributions was never going to fly politically: Even before the government hit troubled waters, meddling with the super guarantee was always laden with risk. title: ASX to drop, Wall St mixed, oil leaps
summary: Australian shares are poised to fall, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq lower as US earnings season kicks off in style. Oil leaps on IEA’s optimism.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open lower, delaying a potential record high reset, as US stocks pulled back even as major banks there far exceeded earnings expectations. Oil was bolstered by a bright demand outlook.', 'ASX futures were down 38 points or 0.6 per cent to 6955 near 7am AEST. In contrast, the currency rallied 1.1 per cent to top US77¢. The yield on the US 10-year note edged up 2 basis points to 1.63 per cent near 5pm in New York.', 'While Coinbase traded higher in its pubic debut in New York, and bitcoin reset its record high, both Coinbase closed down 14 per cent from its opening price at $US328.28. Coinbase’s reference price was $US250.', 'Bitcoin was down 0.6 per cent to $US62,680 near 7.15am AEST on bitstamp.net; it earlier rose as high as $US64,800.', 'On Wall Street stocks were mixed as first-quarter reporting began in earnest with the major banks first off the rank. JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo each reported results ahead of expectations.', '“The bank earnings were strong, but the market expected them to be strong,” Christopher Grisanti, chief equity strategist at MAI Capital Management, told Reuters.', '“So the question becomes how do the bank stocks rise more from here. That’s not clear. They have had a nice ride. I think there will be other places to make money more easily in the future.”', 'The Dow rose 0.2 per cent, paced by Goldman’s 2.3 per cent advance. JPMorgan slid 1.9 per cent after warning about waning demand for loans. Wells Fargo closed up 5.5 per cent.', 'The S&P 500 slid 0.4 per cent; six of its 11 industry groups retreated, paced by consumer discretionary and information technology. The Nasdaq shed 1 per cent.', 'Late this morning will be the latest jobs market check. Here’s what RBC Capital anticipates: “The March labour market snapshot should see job creation continue, with lead vacancy indicators at historically strong levels.', '“There is good reason for near-term caution, though, given that the key JobKeeper wage subsidy program ended at the end of March and hence Q2 labour force reports might show a bit more weakness. Still, with the sample period for today’s report concentrated on the first half of March, our economists expect a solid 40k of net job generation.', '“The number of unemployed could rise a little, though, so our economists think the unemployment rate should tick up from 5.8 per cent to 5.9 per cent.”', 'And here’s St George’s view: “Leading indicators of employment, like weekly payrolls and job vacancies all point to ongoing strong demand for labour. This will hold the unemployment rate steady at 5.8 per cent.', '“Over the remainder of the year, the outlook for jobs is favourable, although we are facing a speed bump with the end of JobKeeper. The massive overhang in global oil inventories that built up during last year’s COVID-19 demand shock is being worked off, vaccine campaigns are gathering pace and the global economy appears to be on a better footing”.', 'The IEA said it had revised up its 2021 global oil demand growth forecast by 230 kb/d. title: ASX to rise, S&P 500 resets record, bitcoin surges
summary: Australian shares are poised to open higher as vaccine concerns and muted US inflation bolstered bullish bets. $A rises. Bitcoin briefly tops $US63,000.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open higher with the S&P 500 resetting yet again its record high, this time amid concerns the US vaccination pace may slow because of a pause in using Johnson & Johnson’s one-shot vaccine.', 'In addition, US consumer prices rose relatively moderately last month, albeit modestly ahead of expectations. Still, the data helped ease concerns about a potential spike in inflation near term. In turn, that could delay the full reopening of the economy.', 'The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were higher at the close, up 0.3 per cent and 1.1 per cent respectively. text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open higher after a four-day long weekend, lifted by another rally in New York. At the top of Tuesday’s agenda is a policy meeting at the Reserve Bank.', 'ASX futures were up 23 points or 0.3 per cent to 6826 when they last traded on April 1. The currency was up 0.5 per cent. The yield on the US 10-year note slipped 1 basis point to 1.71 per cent.', 'On Wall Street, both the Dow and S&P 500 rose to record closing highs, as expected, in the wake of Friday’s March payrolls data. The Dow added 374 points or 1.1 per cent to 33,527.19. The S&P 500 added 58 points or 1.4 per cent to 4077.78.', 'The Nasdaq rose 1.7 per cent, further narrowing its gap to a new record. The tech heavy index lost ground in the first quarter as bond yields rose and investors shifted out of some of 2020’s top advancers.', 'NOTE: With the time change to AEST over the weekend, Wall Street’s closing bell now rings at 6am AEST.', 'The NYSE Fang + Index was 2.1 per cent higher; Alphabet was up 4.1 per cent, Facebook rose 3.4 per cent, Microsoft added 2.8 per cent and Apple advanced 2.4 per cent. Tesla increased 4.4 per cent.', 'Alphabet, Facebook and Microsoft each closed at a record high. Microsoft’s market cap is near $1.88 trillion, Alphabet is near $US1.5 billion and Facebook is near $US880 billion. Apple’s market cap is $US2.11 trillion.', 'Optimism about the US economic outlook got another boost from a survey showing US services industry activity leapt last month. The ISM non-manufacturing activity index surged to 63.7 last month, the highest in the survey’s history, after recording a reading of 55.3 in February.', 'In addition, the US continues to accelerate the vaccination of its population. At least 107.5 million have received at least one jab, representing 40 per cent of the population 18 years and older. title: ASX to rise, tech rally lifts S&P 500 to new high
summary: Australian shares are poised for a modest advance on the first day of April as techs staged a quarter-end rally in New York.
